Award.AwardTitle: Digging deeper: in situ metabolic analysis of soil C cycling processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Healthy soils are essential for maintaining productive natural and agricultural landscapes. Decomposition of dead plant, animal, and microbial materials is a fundamental process that influences ecosystem productivity, the rate of soil erosion, regional hydrology, and the exchange of greenhouse gases with the atmosphere. Because the microbial community plays a key role in decomposition and mineralization, improving the ability to study the microbial processes in soils is a major step towards increased understanding of this essential ecosystem function. The efficiency with which microorganisms process organic carbon compounds for energy production and biosynthesis, or return carbon back to the atmosphere as CO2, is an essential but poorly understood aspect of soil ecology. A change in the carbon use efficiency --- the fraction of substrate used for the production of new microbial biomass in response to increased temperatures or litter input --- will have immediate consequences for soil carbon content, CO2 production, and nutrient cycling. This project will examine changes in the fundamental processes of microbial metabolism from which carbon use efficiency, energy production, and biosynthesis can be calculated. The investigators will use a method that consists of stable isotope labeling of specific C-atoms in various microbial substrates under different conditions of temperature, carbon and nitrogen availability. This study will make use of an existing long-term climate change experiment near Flagstaff, Arizona.

The approach used in this study can be directly applied to other microbial communities, for example communities in marine and freshwater ecosystems and sediments, gastrointestinal communities, communities in environments such as hot springs, and in waste-water treatment plants. Results from this study will improve the representation of soil carbon dynamics in ecosystem models that are used to understand the role of soil processes in the global carbon cycle under current and future climates. This study will also provide opportunities for one graduate student and several undergraduate students to become familiar with state-of-the-art stable isotope techniques, molecular characterization of microbial communities, and interpretation of biochemical processes in soil ecosystems. Finally, results will be incorporated into an undergraduate ecology and ecosystem science curriculum.

Project Outcomes Report

     It is important to understand what microbes are doing in soils. Soils contain a large amount of C that is vulnerable to disturbances, such as climate change, forest fires, land-use, and agricultural practices. If a substantial amount of the C stored gets released into the atmosphere because of increased microbial activity, it will contribute to future climate change, while simultaneous loss of nutrients from the soil will affect soil health, stability, and reduce ecosystem and agricultural productivity.

     There are different views on what microbes are doing in soil. On the one hand, there are soil ecologists that think that soil does not contain enough energy-rich substrates for microbes to be active. In their view, in this C-limited environment, microbes spend most of their substrate on producing ATP to maintain the cell but do not grow. On the other hand, there are those who believe that microbes in soil are actively growing and dying. These two extreme points of views, and all possibilities in between, affect the value of C use efficiency (CUE, the amount of growth that occurs for a given amount of substrate consumed). For microbes that use substrate only to maintain the cell, the CUE should equal zero, while for microbes that are actively growing, the CUE will be around 0.7. This value of CUE is an important microbial characteristic that greatly affects the outcome of soil C cycling models, and thus the prediction of how soil C storage will be affected with changes in the environment.

     Most experiments that measure CUE add variable amounts of substrate (for example glucose) to soils and measure how much of the substrate-C is released as CO2 and how much remains in the microbial biomass. Other approaches use models of element ratio relationships between microbial growth and substrate. These methods have measured a large variation in CUE values. These methods can be criticized for 1) adding fairly large amounts of substrate to soil thus potentially overestimating CUE, 2) insufficiently separating microbial metabolic processes and microbial turnover, resulting in an underestimation of CUE, and 3) not providing insights in the responses of the basic processes that are at the heart of biosynthesis and energy production in microbial cells and determine CUE.

     We developed a method for measuring CUE that is based on the production of CO2 from position-specific 13C-labeled compounds in parallel 40-min incubations, and combined it with a model of glycolysis, TCA cycle, and pentose phosphate pathway to calculate CUE. We further developed this method to test specific assumptions regarding microbial metabolism (for example storage production versus active balanced cell growth), studied the sensitivity of the basic metabolic pathways to their environment (temperature and C availability), and developed models that estimate the isotope incorporation of the 13C-label into DNA and lipids. The latter models can be used to develop techniques to determine taxon-specific CUE in complex intact microbial communities.

     The results of our measurements show that CUE is generally high (based on qualitative and quantitative interpretation). We also did not see the expected decrease of CUE with temperature (until 30-40°C), and were able to show that speculation that microbes use the added substrate for storage, but not for growth, were unfounded. Finally, we showed that high temperature stress causes a shutdown of the TCA-cycle within one hour, but this temperature damage is reversed after overnight incubation.
